Name: Hit Parade
Description:
A Finnish trivia game about pop music, with 3000 questions of the rock-pop-disco-soul scene of the 1960's to 1980's.

The number of players is not specified so the only limit is practicality; the game lasts until a pre-agreed number of points or rounds played.

This is the Finnish edition, with somewhat localized content of the Finnish music scene, of a Swedish game published around the same time in the eighties by Kärnan as Popgeni. Swedish content translated by Eero Mattila.

Name: Conny
Description:
You have been on a riding vacation on a farm for a few weeks. One day you notice nine horses being stolen by 4 horse thieves. You quickly discover where the horses are hidden, and then the big race begins.

You must ride out and find the horses which are hidden in the mountains, but many dangers lures, and the thieves can surprise you. Once the horses are found they must be returned to the farm, and the player who returns the most valuable horses is the winner.

An exciting and entertaining game for all horse-loving girls and boys.

Name: Tosipeli
Description: There are 54 cards containing beginnings of sentences. Players should continue these sentences and the most creative player emerges as the winner in the end.

Name: DogTales B.C.
Description:
The object of the game is to bring your dog through the board and collect all 4 items. This game aimed at children has the premise of "What would happen if dogs evolved instead of humans?" A simple game, much like it's sibling-game : Dogtales in Outer Space (GAME ID 17668)

This game is aimed at kids from 3 to 6 years old, according to the rules.

From the box :
Be the first player to collect 'The Cavepainter's Palette', 'The Cookout Spear', 'Fire Sticks' and 'The Big Round Turning Thing That's Fun to Chase' pieces for each player.

Name: Who's on First?
Description:
The hilarious guessing game based on the famous all-time classic comedy routine.

Game players try to guess where their opponents have placed their players on the baseball diamond playing board, and the player guessing the locations of all players in the fewest number of guesses is the winner.

Name: De Grote Geschiedenisshow: Het Egypte van de Farao's
Description:
The gameboard represents a maze build up of rooms connected with corridors.

Each player starts by placing their locked & unlocked key-cards face down in the corridors. They then place their explorer at the starting point of the maze.

The movement is done by a dice roll. If you enter a corridor with a locked key you can't move. If you choose not to roll the dice you may also swap 2 key-cards on the board.

Some rooms have a special symbol that leads to a special action. For example: Skip a turn, take a chance card, return the way you came, enter a secret passage or a (hard!) question about ancient Egypt.

The final goal of the game is to find the door that hides the treasures of Tutanchamon. That player wins the game.

Name: Affenstark
Description: Bausack light for kids. Roll a die. Place one or two wooden bananas on a pile of bananas which are held by Carla (bigger monkey) or do nothing or place Alfons (smaller monkey) on top the banana pile. If you can manage it you’ll get 2 victory points, if not (pile crashes) you’ll lose one. First one with 9 VP wins.

Name: Mondreise
Description:
Childrens' game about little sandmen who are searching to find the other half of the moon.

There are three rule variants which can be played. The first involves matching face down pieces of the moon to complete the  seven different ones. In the second variant the sandmen race to the moon along a track of halves. They are only allowed to move to a new space if they can find the other half between the face down pieces. The third involves all players searching for a matching piece at the same time.

The game aims at the very young (3 to 5).

Name: The Sky's the Limit
Description:
"The Sky's the Limit" is described as a game of aircraft trading and management. It was published by BAE Systems, the British aerospace and defense company, as a promotional product.

The aim of the game is to travel from your starting city, purchase at least one aircraft from the bank whilst at a city in each continent, and then return to your starting city, making the most of all business opportunities en route. Along the way, you will encounter opportunities to improve you journey or your financial situation, or events that conspire against you.

An interesting extract from the rules: "The most trustworthy player is chosen as the banker. If a trustworthy player can't be agreed upon, the banker shall be the oldest player."

Name: Komische Autos
Description:
A childrens game consisting of 60 cards divided into 3 groups with 20 cards each: front, middle and rear parts of automobiles.

Game is played by each player combining a card of each group to one automobile each turn. This will produce comical results which will make the children laugh. Then players can trade parts of the cars to create proper cars. You score points for each proper automobile completed.

Name: The Book Game
Description:
"The Book Game" consists of 4000 questions and answers (1000 designed especially for children) taken from "The Book" (a version of the Bible).

A "Question & Answer" game (ala Trivial Pursuit).  Correctly answer a question and advance your pawn one space. Be the first to reach the "Finish" space by advancing your pawn seven spaces.  On your turn, instead of answering a question to advance your pawn, you may choose to "block" an opponent by correctly answering a question.  Blocks are removed by correctly answering questions.  Advancement only occurs if a pawn is not "blocked."

Questions are divided into two sets: The Old and New Testaments.  A die roll (50-50 chance) determines which set of questions a question is drawn from on your turn.

Name: The Beaver Tooth Game
Description:
Anybody studying the history of the American Indians? 
For an innovative addition to your curriculum, you might try Beaver Tooth, a game played for centuries by the "First People of the Pacific Northwest."

The game includes a woven basket, four carved beaver teeth (dice), and a bundle of "counting bones." (In the original game, the beaver teeth were real teeth and the counting bones, bird bones; in the modern version, both are reproductions, made from bone-colored polymer.)

The game is simple, fast-paced, and fun: depending on the fall of the carved teeth, players win counting bones; the player with the most bones at the end of the game wins.

An accompanying color-illustrated booklet (Beaver Tooth: An Authentic Game from the First People of the Pacific Northwest by David G. Gordon & Mike Kowalski) contains a native legend about the origin of the beaver, historical background information about the Indian tribes of the Pacific Northwest, a list of related reading suggestions, and a history of the Beaver Tooth game.

For two or more players, aged 6 and up. $19.95; from the Skookum Jump Rope Co., Box 1159, Port Townsend, WA 98368; (800) 255-9526; fax (360) 379-9049.

Authentic good fun.

Partial proceeds help support the United Indians of All Tribes Foundation.

Name: Tower Climb
Description:
"OBJECT: BEAT YOUR OPPONENTS OVER THE WALL"

"A SKILL GAME OF COOPERATION"

A transparent plastic hexagonal tower about 12" high with holes in the sides is separated into two compartments by a semi-transparent plastic dividing wall.  Each player drops three plastic balls of their respective color into the closest section; the balls have small holes on their surfaces. Each player is given two small plastic spear-like devices which are used to maneuver the balls over the dividing wall into the opponent's section.

The first person to get their three balls over the dividing wall wins the round. The first person to win three rounds wins the game.

The rules also suggest that teams of two can compete, with each player given one plastic spear.

Name: Humpty Dumpty game
Description:
From the publisher:
Oh dear, Humpty Dumpty's had a great fall! Can you help the king's men? Spin the big 3-D spinner and try to collect the matching colored pieces to put Humpty together again. A fun game for 6 players, based on the enduringly popular nursery rhyme.

Links with Early Learning Goals in Personal, Social and Emotional Development; and Creative Development.

Name: YPAW: Young People At Work
Description: YPAW is a children's game made to help players memorize 20 Bible verses. Pieces of a charm bracelet are drawn from a bag which are linked to one of the verses. An instructor reads a question about the verse aloud; if the player answers the question and recites the verse properly, he or she keeps the charm. Otherwise, other players get a chance to answer. The first player to get four correct answers wins.

Name: Runebound: Avatars of Kelnov
Description:
From the Fantasy Flight Games Website:

"The Avatars of Kelnov expansion pack is a whole new adventure set in the Runebound land of Terrinoth! In a time before time, the gods banished the wrathful All-Father Kelnov and his Avatars, out of this world and out of history. His return is prophecied to herald in an age of peace - but whether it will be an age of peace under a tyrannical god, or an age of peace and freedom, is up to the heroes to determine ...

The Avatars of Kelnov adventure variant replaces some elements of the Rise of the Dragon Lords adventure found in the Runebound: Second Edition base game, creating an entirely new game experience! It includes 30 new adventure cards."

Belongs to the Runebound Series.

Expands:

    Runebound: Second Edition

Name: Runebound: Cult of the Rune
Description:
From the Fantasy Flight Games website:

"The Cult of the Rune expansion pack is a whole new adventure set in the Runebound land of Terrinoth! The Dwarves of Forge have uncovered something best left hidden. No one seems to know where these ancient Runes came from, but their power is undeniable ... and pernicious. The Runes have managed to twist those around them into worshiping them like gods, and now ... they are spreading.

The Cult of the Rune adventure variant replaces some elements of the Rise of the Dragon Lords adventure found in the Runebound: Second Edition base game, creating an entirely new game experience! It includes 30 new adventure cards and a set of cardboard tokens."

Belongs to the Runebound Series.

Expands:

    Runebound: Second Edition

Name: Runebound: Drakes and Dragonspawn
Description:
From the Fantasy Flight Games Website:

"The Drakes and Dragonspawn expansion pack introduces a flight of new hazards, challenges, quests, and events as the drakes and their ilk spread across the world. These cards can be seamlessly added to any Runebound: Second Edition game, providing all new adventure and rewards!

This expansion includes 30 new adventure cards."

Belongs to the Runebound Series.

Expands:

    Runebound: Second Edition

Name: Runebound: Walkers of the Wild
Description:
From the Fantasy Flight Games Website:

"The Walkers of the Wild expansion pack introduces a collection of allies that dwell in the secret and quiet places of the world, as well as many tricks of their trade. These cards can be seamlessly added to any Runebound: Second Edition game or adventure, giving the players more options and more adventure!

This expansion includes 30 new market deck cards."

Belongs to the Runebound Series.

Expands:

    Runebound: Second Edition

Name: Sudoku Taisen 4x4: The Great Battle of Sudoku
Description:
Taisen, a Japanese word for Great Battle.  Now you know ... But are you ready?  Are you ready for the Great Battle of Sudoku!

4x4 grid with 432 ways to play and you are the puzzle!

In Sudoku Taisen 4x4, it is much more challenging to complete your grid because you are sharing 8 squares (shared squares are called Taisen Square) with your opponent(s). Your opponents can place a number to prevent you from completing your grid.  Therefore, you need to stack your opponent's number with your desired number, so you may complete your grid.  Your opponents will surely do the same to you.  Furthermore, additional challenge, your fate of winning also depends on your dice roll and the Taisen Card you draw.

Contents:
20 Taisen Cards
88 Chips
1 Die
1 Board (two sides)
1 Manual

Board is designed for two or four players.  It can also be used for one player and three players.

Related to:

    Sudoku Taisen 6x6: The Great Battle of Sudoku

Name: Die Troll Familie
Description:
Simple memory game for children 5 years and older. Each player places their troll at the start of a path, with each space on the path showing a fruit corresponding to a fruit marker. The fruit markers are placed face down on the table and shuffled.

On their turn, a player turns over a fruit token. If it shows the same fruit as the next space on the player's path, the player's troll moves to that space; if not, the troll stays where it is. In any case, the token is put back, face down, and it's the next player's turn. The player whose troll reaches the end of the path first, wins.

Contents: 1 game board, 4 trolls, 7 round fruit markers

Name: Migration Game
Description: Each player starts out with a flock of 500 geese and 100 energy points.  By rolling the die and following the instructions on the cards, players simulate the full migration of their flock.  Along the way, each player's flock will encounter conditions, both favorable and unfavorable, that actual geese might face during their annual migration.  The player who completes the migration with the highest score is the winner.

Name: Water Cycle Game
Description: With a roll of the dice and a spin of the wheel, players flow through the various components of the water cycle on their way back to the ocean.  The game helps players understand the hydro-logic behind evaporation, transpiration, condensation, precipitation, the concept of ground water versus land runoff and the complexity of the water cycle.

Name: Life Cycle Game
Description: Players learn about the four-part life cycle of both a Monarch butterfly and a green bean plant.  The first player to collect all eight life cycle cards and reach the finish circle wins.  The game comes with an extra 25 question cards for upper-level play.

Name: The Kaleidoscope Game
Description: There are five spheres on each side of the board, represented by diamond-shaped color crystals in the center of the board.  Each player has four markers which he or she moves around the board trying to collect the crystals.  When a player has collected all the crystals of the same color, he or she has a color ring.  The winner is the first player to collect a fixed number of color rings (depending on the number of players).

Name: Bonkers
Description:
Cards come in four categories: fill-in-the-blank, add-ons, rhyme time, and letter perfect. In the first three, a 'keyword' is announced, and an opposing player or team tries to name the four additional words on the card that are related to the 'keyword' in the same way. That is, all four i) can fill in the blank to form a two-word phrase with the keyword, or ii) can be added to the keyword to form a new word, or iii) can be rhymed with the keyword. In the letter perfect category, the player must name the four words that fit a topic and that use a letter in the same way, eg, boys' names beginning with 'M'.

The team that reads the question also ranks the four items from easiest to hardest. The harder the item, the further forward a team moves for guessing it. Each opposing team gets one chance to name unguessed items.

Name: Shotgun Slade
Description: Shotgun Slade has captured 4 outlaws in different locations around this frontier town. The players, his deputies, must bring them in and lock them up. The first player to get all four of his outlaws (marbles) around the board and into his four jail holes by exact count, wins the game.  Much like Aggravation

Name: Woody Woodpecker's Moon Dash
Description: Simple spin-and-move game as Woody Woodpecker races around a board with attractive moon graphics.

Name: Disneyland
Description: The players walk around Disneyland. When you land on a ride/attraction you are allowed to rent it. If you land on a ride/attraction that another player owns you have to pay him an entrance fee. The entrance fee increases when the player has several attractions of the same set.

Name: Breakout from the Crimea: Wrangel's Offensive
Description:
Breakout From the Crimea covers General Wrangel's Russian White Army offensive from their trapped environs of the Crimea. Wrangel and his 25,000 men were evacuated from Novorisisk in March 1920, later reforming and re-supplied by the British. The Red 13th army was responsible for Wrangel's containment, as well as the Communist's attempt to break through to Sevastopol. In April, both sides tried in vain to achieve their goals.

Wrangel's forces were not numerically as strong as the 13th Army, but their morale, as well as skillful use of tanks and aircraft, returned the balance of power to their favor. By May 1920, Wrangel had up to 20 operational tanks and an equal number of DH9A bombers. Their tankers and pilots trained since March, and learned well the lessons taught by their British advisors in combined arms tactics.

During the battle, both sides fought tenaciously, but it was the use of tanks and aircraft that tipped the scales. The DH9A bombers faced little Red air opposition and ï¬‚ew constant missions over the front. The tanks were massed into a hammering force for a breakthrough. All of these lessons were ignored by Wrangel's former superior, General Denikin, a year earlier. To supplement the attack, Wrangel also had several divisions land along the Black Sea coast, which was weakly held by the Communists. By June 12th, the Communist 13th Army lost 8,000 men and was ï¬‚eeing to the protection of the Dniepr River. Wrangel, lost nearly the same amount and exploiting the White victory was not easy. The Reds counter-attacked a few days later and brieï¬‚y retook Melitopol. Eventually, the

Whites recaptured the city and the lines became static, with neither side having the strength to overcome the other.

Components 
(High Flying dice edition):

    Four 11" x 17" map sections
    Two sheets of 280 playing pieces
    One Players' Aid Sheet
    One, 12 page rule book


(Firefight edition):

    one 11 x 17 map
    280 DTP counters

Name: Larry Burkett's Money Matters
Description:
Players roll and move around the board, collecting income and paying off bills.  Each player has 14 envelopes, each representing various categories of expenses, and whoever pays them all off first by placing the correct amount of money in each envelope, wins.

From the rule book:

"Stewardship means taking care of our possessions, knowing that everything we have actually belongs to God. A key goal of this game is to teach that it is not how much money people have but their stewardship that is important. Players learn that (1) they can reach their financial goals by budgeting their money carefully and (2) it pays to be generous."

Name: Puzzle Perfection
Description:
Roll the die, and it'll show one of 6 colors.  Pick a piece of that color, and fit it into your 5x5 rack.  If there are no pieces left of the color rolled, then steal one of that color from someone else's rack!  When someone gets a full rack, the round ends.

Each of the 6 colors contain 7 pieces: 3 odd-shaped 5-square pieces (with 3 symbols), 1 3-square 'corner' (with 2 symbols), 1 2-square (with 1 symbol), and 2 1-squares.

Scoring is achieved by matching the symbols either beside each other, or at angles, for 1 point per unique pair.  If you can't fit a piece in your rack, you get -1 per piece.  If you achieved the full rack, and called PUZZLE PERFECTION to end the round, then you get 5 extra points.

The game is played for several rounds, as agreed upon before the game started.

Name: How To Build a Nucleotide
Description: The game is played like the basic "Rummy" or "500" card games.  Drawing from the hand they are dealt, the deck and/or the discard pile, players try to obtain the proper cards to build as many nucleotides and complementary base pairs as possible.  Each deck includes 94 cards - 10 cytosine, 10 adenine, 10 guanine, 10 thymine, 10 hydrogen bonding, 20 phosphate, 20 sugar, and 4 wild.

Name: ERG: The Energy Resource Game
Description: This Rummy-style card game teaches about the transport and use of renewable and non-renewable resources.  Players must overcome natural disasters, depleted resources, and conservation efforts.  The Teacher's Manual, which comes separately, offers more comprehensive information on the game topics.

Name: Chase-Bots
Description:
It all comes down to this. You are competing against rival corporations for a multi trillion-dollar contract. You are up against the most brilliant robotics engineers in the Solar system.

Each opponent will deploy a squadron of four robots representing decades of development and billions of dollars in material and research.

Your goal: Infiltrate your opponent’s home stations while preventing all of them from doing the same.

But wait! There’s a catch. A single Intercepting Trapper robot represents the previous champion. The I.T. robot will capture and imprison any other robot it comes into contact with.

You will have to use all of your best programming skill. Employ on the fly upgrades to your robots to make them more formidable, more elusive and more intelligent. Of course, your rivals will all be doing the same!

A description of the game itself:

Each player controls a squad of four Chase-Bots. The object is to get your robots into the starting spaces of your opponents. Game play is in three phases.

1.    The Programming Phase
2.    The Reveal Phase
3.    The Movement Phase

In the Programming Phase, each player selects one card from their hand and places it face down in front of them.

In the Reveal Phase players simultaneously turn their cards over. Turn order for each round is determined by the values of the cards.

In the Movement Phase, each player moves his Chase-bots in turn.

The last player to move one of his Chase-bots into the main play area is the first to be IT. He must capture another Chase-bot with the black IT robot before he can move his own Chase-bots again. This makes one of the other players IT.

Throughout the game players will be installing, stealing and interfering with each other’s Upgrades. Upgrades give each player additional abilities such as alternative ways of moving their robots, increasing their hand size and any of up to 30 special powers.

Special Trigger cards add to the excitement as players wrest turn order from each other, steal upgrades from one another and basically sabotage their opponents.

Playground tag was never quite like this!

Name: Numéphrase
Description:
Numéphrase (can be translate by Numbered phrase) is a trivia game.

On each of the 500 cards, you can find a phrase beginning with a number. Only the first letter of each word appears. The active player must find the complete sentence. Example: 3 C_____ on the F___ of F_____. B___, W_____ and R__; the solution appear on the back of the card: 3 Colors on the Flag of France. Blue, White and Red.

Traveling on the board with a roll and move mechanism, you can also collect hint cards to facilitate up coming sentences to guess.

I think this self-published game was only available in French.

The box contain:

- 1 Game board
- 500 phrase cards
- 50 key cards
- 25 domain cards
- 12 pawns
- 1 die

Name: Kung Fu U
Description:
John could not believe his luck. His first day at Kung Fu University, and already he was involved in a duel. He had trained all his life to be able to test his skills in the martial arts, and here he was already getting a chance.

As he stood his ground, his tiger claw held high and ready, John watched his foe. She was a little thing, all dressed up in a bright floral dress with a blue ribbon in her hair. Maybe after the duel, they could go get a glass of milk together he thought to himself.

That’s when she hit him.

Waking up on the grass, John rubbed his chin where the girl in the flower dress had hit him. She stood over him offering a hand up.

“Your Kung Fu was good, but mine was better,” she said with a smile as she walked away.

Maybe school would be a bit tougher then he thought, John mused as he chased after her, asking if she could show him how she did that kick.

This is Kung Fu U, the game of martial arts combat and fun times. Can you out fight your foes before they bring you down with a surprise attack. Can your Kung Fu out shine your foe’s skills. Find out who is the best of the best with this exciting Mini-game from Bad Baby Productions.

(From the game):

1999
In 1936 we changed the world. 
Altered the course of history. And of man.
Now the past has caught up with you.
This is your war.

With every 1999 miniatures package you get a complete rulebook as well as the rules for the miniature you purchased. This allows you to get started immediately collecting and playing with miniatures for any of three core factions. The game will only be sold in blister boxes and each blister box will contain a rulebook, so each blister box is a Starter. The first release is five blister boxes for each of the three core factions: Angels, Demons and Men. Each model has a full color card with its rules in local language attached to the front of the blister box.
Due to the modified genetic code of many warriors, you can tailor the programming of their DNA before every battle, tweaking your chosen tactic to gain momentum and moment of surprise, every time you play an opponent. Even the same opponent.

Â· Highly detailed expressive miniatures.
Â· Scalable system allows you to play with any number of miniatures.
Â· Tactical and fast-paced dynamic rules for retro-futuristic warfare.
Â· Unique genetic ability tweaking and deployment system.
Â· Complete rulebook comes with all miniatures.
Â· Affiliation/value indicators makes army construction and modification a breeze.
Â· Experience the advantages and spectacular drawbacks when man's tampering with creation backfires.
Â· Each miniature comes with full color rules card.
Â· Epic dark gothic setting and artwork.

Name: Haltet den Dieb
Description:
This game uses a similar mechanism as later used by Baggage Claim aka Wettflug (Randolph) and The Prestel New York Architecture Game (Fackler): 
There are ten stacks of cards. The cards tell the story of 8 thieves, each story consists of 5 parts. All parts are shuffled. Now, on a turn, a player can take 1 pile and look at the top 3 cards, choosing one of them (he doesn't have to take a card). As soon as someone has all 5 pieces of one story together, he wins the game. The problem is, that you have to take the parts in the right order, you don't know what parts the other players have (the parts 1 & 2 are all three times available, 3 two times, the 4th and 5th part only once), so you have to memorize the right stacks.

Name: Treppauf: Treppab
Description:
The "board" is a 3-dimensional house. The players are family members who have to reach different destinations with dice to accomplish certain household chores (like washing dishes). The first one to finish all his chores and reaching the swimming pool before another player manages to tack further work on him, wins. 
The whole gaming materials are bilingual, in French and German.

Under license from Seven Towns Ltd., London

Name: Heimgolfi
Description: This is basically trick golf for the dinner table: The game parts allow to set up 10 "official" obstacles (the courses have a length of about 30cm) and the player take turns of trying to hit the ball in the hole.

Name: Vakkari
Description: An educational Finnish card game published by the University of Oulu. There are 2 decks of cards. One contains cards about studying, the other about working. On each turn the player draws a card and tries to get as many studying or working points as possible.

Name: Mr. Mad
Description:
"Make him mad and he will spin...
Throwing marbles so you can win!"

Mr. Mad requires 2 D-cell batteries.
 The object of the game is to be the first player to get rid of all their marbles.

All players select a particular colored group of marbles to represent them during the game.  Players start the game with 8 marbles; all do not belong to that player but are divided as equally as possible between the relevant colors selected.  A turn consists of dropping 1-3 marbles one at a time into the mouth of Mr. Mad, a plastic robot about 10" high.  Players are required to state the color of marble to be introduced into Mr Mad's mouth prior to doing so.

On the floor of his transparent mouth is a button; if a marble hits this button the mechanism inside Mr Mad is triggered, causing him to spin around, flinging the marbles in his mouth out through large gaps where his hands would otherwise be.  The player represented by the marble which activated Mr Mad must switch him off with the special 'stopping rod' provided as quickly as possible, as all marbles flung from mr Mad are collected by that player.

Name: Man the Lifeboat
Description:
From the Game Rules:

"Man the Lifeboat" is an exciting, fast moving Family Game where the players in effect become the Coxswain of the Lifeboat, responding to Mayday Signals of Vessels in Distress.  The game also serves as a tribute to the men of the Royal National Lifeboat Institution whose real life endeavors were the inspiration behind this game.

Man The Lifeboat’ is an exciting fast moving game for all the family (player age 7+).

Contents
1 PLAYING BOARD    
2 DRIFT DICE (2D10 marked N,S,E,W,NE,SE,NW,SW,Anchor,Sunk)
2 CO-ORDINATE DICE (2D20 in Red,Black)
4 LIFEBOAT DICE    (4D6 in Orange,Yellow,Green,Blue) 
1 DICE CUP
4 ‘ALL WEATHER’ LIFEBOATS (Orange,Yellow,Green,Blue)
4 ‘INFLATABLE’ LIFEBOATS (Orange,Yellow,Green,Blue)
2 VESSELS IN DISTRESS (One black, One Red)
24 CARDS (Vessels rescued)
4 SERVICES RENDERED HOLDERS (for recoding rescues)

Name: Tasten in het Duister
Description:
Kleptonauts are hunting the dark and empty universe for Lux supplies. They are raiding neighboring planets and settlements as well as each other to get to these supplies. Their only real concern however is that they don't run out of space rum! If you can keep their ships stocked with run they will most likely do your bidding and make you the richest man in the universe.

Players bid space rum for control of each of the 6 kleptonaut ships each turn. If they gain control they can move them to pick op Lux treasures and/or deliver them to their own space stations which will generate money. The player with the most money at the end of the game wins.

Name: A Nation on Trial
Description:
A Nation on Trial is an operational level miniature battle simulation system. The game includes easy to use rules for command-control, supply, and designing historical campaigns.
Featuring:

     The same basing system as the Tactical-Level system Johnny Reb.
     Rules for command-control, supply and the fog of war
     Big battles such as Antietam are playable in a 4'x 8' space.
     Big battles can be played in either a day or a weekend.
     The Three Days of Gettysburg: a ready to play scenario for A Nation on Trial.
     Ratings for over fifty different divisions, corps and army commanders for the Union and Confederacy.


Expanded by:

    Blow! Bugles! Blow!

Name: Octopus
Description: Players are divided into teams of two. Each player dons head, wrist, and ankle Velcro™ straps. A team starts the game standing. The JUMBO cube is then rolled twice and the team then connects the appropriate Velcro™ straps according to the colors rolled on the JUMBO cube. Play continues until a team wins the game by being the first to complete 25 connections.

Name: UnVeiled
Description: A bachelorette bash in a box! Just what you need to throw a fun and sexy party for the bride-to-be. Customize the board with photos of the bride, have her fiancé fill out the special questionnaire, gather some friends and start playing. Just roll the die and use the utterly adorable shoe-shaped game pieces to move along the board. Choose the activity cards you want to create the perfect event (from the tame "sing a Madonna song with only vowel sounds" to the wilder "lick and kiss a stranger's tattoo"). Includes recipes and suggestions for three types of bachelorette party, from an intimate (and inexpensive) evening in to a lavish night on the town. The bride-to-be and up to 30 players can participate

Name: StarSlide
Description:
StarSlide ... an abstract strategy game of placement and movement played on a laser-cut wood game board.

The object is to be the last to slide a star.

Two players use 6, three players use 4, four players use 3 glass stars each.

The board has 13 'points' in a circle, connected by 4 paths each to 4 other points.

Players take turns to place, slide and mark one of their stars.

A player may block the centre of the board for one turn and also 'freeze' opponent's stars out of the game.

Glass stars were originally included as playing pieces ... now, acrylic discs.

StarSlide also includes 4 solitaire puzzles.

Name: Quirky!
Description:
Quirky is an abstract strategy board game of luck (of the draw), placement (strategy), stacking and points accumulation on a triangular wooden board.

Based on the number '3' and designed for three players by Games Above Board, the (Canadian) publisher states Quirky may also be played by two players.

Each player has a colour (which may change during the game) and, taking turns, draws different-shaped pieces at random from a bag - placing them on the board regardless of the owner yet being careful not to help the opponent(s) nor hinder their own strategy.

Should the colours change, players retain their points scored and continue playing against what was previously their own color pieces and strategy.

Pieces may be placed 3-high and top pieces may be removed.

Placement or exposure of 3 same-colour pieces in a triangle scores 3 points.

The object is to be the first to score 45 points.

Name: Buckeyes!
Description:
10 Scenarios covering the 37th (Buckeye) Infantry Division on New Georgia and Bougainville in 1943-44.
 Hill 700, Bougainville, March9,1944. 
The fanatic Japanese attack resulted in a slim but dangerous penetration. The Japanese 23rd Infantry Regiment had captured several strategic positions on the crest of Hill 700, including seven pillboxes, and had moved light and heavy machine guns into the American trenches and pillboxes. Now the Japanese were in position to put fire on the American supply routes beyond the hill. The Japanese would have to be thrown off the hill — the only question was how. 
On the morning of March 9, the Buckeyes launched several scattered counterattacks with no results. At noon, the 145th Infantry made its first major effort, sending elements of two battalions up the hills with tank support. However, the tanks could not operate on the hill and the Buckeyes could only seize a few pillboxes. Air and artillery bombardment, including point blank fire,could not dislodge the Japanese. At 1700 on March 10, the two battalions attacked again, making some progress, but on March 11 the Japanese counterattacked, taking another pillbox at heavy expense. The 145th’s commander, Colonel Whitcomb, was relieved for “extreme battle fatigue”. 
 New Georgia Island, July 18, 1943.
The American assault on New Georgia was spearheaded by the 43rd ID, with the Buckeyes of the 37th ID in reserve. The 43rd ID, as untried as the 37th, ran into difficulties in its drive towards Munda Airfield and began to fall apart. The 37th ID was committed in mid-July. However, in addition to stopping the American advance, Japanese General Noburo Sasaki sent infiltrating units to cut the Munda Trail, which served as the tenuous U.S. supply line from the far away beachhead. One group of Japanese hit the rear-echelon defenders of a supply and ammo dump at Parachute Drop, defended by the newly arrived Ammunition and Anti-Tank Platoons of the 1st Battalion, 145th Infantry.
 Mark Pitcavage's Buckeyes!:
The 37th (Buckeye) Infantry Division on New Georgia and Bougainville in 1943-44
The Pacific Theater at its Best

Name: Berlin-Bummel
Description:
Translated from box back:
Berlin has always been worth a journey, not only in today's time but for 750 years, because while the city was old then it is still much older today. Let yourself be captivated by the game of Berlin at the turn of the century. A stroll is worthwhile in itself as theaters, museums and much more besides lure you as you make your way into the city center seeing the sights. Enjoy again the splendor of old Berlin. An excursion into the outlying districts is worthwhile in itself as well. You will be astonished if suddenly a citizen of old Berlin emerges before you. Thus it goes as the train pulls in to platform 3 of the Goerlitzer station. “Everybody off!”, calls the station master.

Game summary:
Players travel the streets of turn of the 19th century Berlin via foot, subway and horse carriage trying to see as many sights as possible. The first player to collect advertisements from ten attractions, or find the hidden anniversary pin, and make it to the finish station wins. Along the way players may encounter citizens of Berlin which will send them off to various parts of the city.

Name: Cat's Pajamas
Description:
From The Box:

"Time for beddie-bye!  Have no fear, even at night, when the lights are off, you can play a game of Cat's Pajamas because the cards GLOW IN THE DARK!

And turning the lights on and off are actually part of the game!  See if you can match the most sets of sleepy kitties.  Each one has its own unique glow in the dark pattern printed on either their jammies or their blankie.

Remember to check your sheets for BED BUGS.  They can creep up on you and take one of your matched pairs.  And that nasty ALARM CLOCK will stir up a startle and force a re-deal that will totally interrupt your sleep!"

Name: MoNoPOLi Board Game
Description: In the game MoNoPOLi (Molybdenum, Nobelium, Polonium, Oxygen, Lithium), players try to acquire complete sets of element groups including alkaline Earth metals, d-transition metals and halogens, while answering questions regarding lab ware, chemical principles, periodic table trends and more.  Along the way, they try to avoid Unfavorable Enthalpy and Binding Energy and hope to land on a Reaction Pathway Shortcut.

Name: Up 'N' Under
Description:
Up N Under!

The Rugby board game for all Rugby Players, Rugby Fans, and Referees worldwide.

If your favorite Rugby team gets knocked out of the Cup, don’t despair just open up your “Up N Under” Rugby board game and carry on playing on this perfectly packaged portable game.

This is a Quikky dice rolling game with simple rules for 2 players of any age from 9 to 99 or more and each player plays the full 80 minutes or less if you prefer.

Ideal entertainment anytime anywhere - in the playground, in the back of the car, on the train, on the plane, on the beach, in the club house, in the changing rooms at half time or anywhere you fancy – any time is Quikky time.

Comes in one of several formats including: pocket travel case (using coins for randomization), slim-line case, tuf-case, birthday card, greeting card, or beermat coaster.

Name: Insomnio
Description: This is an old children's game, its a boardgame in which you use cards to try to sleep 12 hours while you bother other players.

Name: Von nix kommt nix
Description: The players (or teams) will take two roles in this game: They are buying and selling product of development countries, aiming for a high product. At the same time, they are consumers which will buy products of developed countries, having an eye on the price, but also on several guaranteed values, coming with the goods (i.e. boycott products which might have used child labor).

Name: Eve's Quest
Description: Trivia game celebrating women with over 1,000 questions from Mother Teresa to Mother Goose.  Something for everyone: charades, drawing, singing, intuition challenges and of course trivia, proving that girls got game, indeed!

Name: Nerdy Wordy Crossword Game
Description: From the website:  Players alternate turns, selecting letter cubes that both players must use to spell words by dropping the cubes into the tray.  Create as many 2-5 letter words as possible and score bonus points by spelling words within words.

Name: Napoleon
Description: One player plays the 21 pieces of the French army (including Napoleon). The other player plays the 25 pieces of the English army (including Wellington) and the 12 pieces of the Prussian army (including Blücher). The game depicts the battle of Waterloo, and is played on a somewhat abstract map with squares and lines between them to symbolize movement possibilities. All French and English pieces have their fixed starting positions on the board. The Prussian pieces have numbers on them, and come into play on a square marked "P", on the game turn with their number. The game is played over ten turns. The goal for France is to hold two specific squares marked with red crosses. The goal for the allies is to hold two squares marked with blue crosses.

Name: Tannenberg
Description:
The opening days of World War One in the East.

Test Series Game 8.  Sister game to Dunnigan's 1914.  Designed at the same time as the 1914: Revision Kit; uses the 1914 system.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Codebreaker
Description: Pair-matching memory game a la "Concentration", with the twist that you can write your own code on the backs of cards you see, and try to figure out others' codes.

Name: TimeTripper
Description:
From the Publisher's website:

Introducing Timetripper™, the game with a past and an attitude. History appears right before players' eyes as they travel back in time to remember important events, pop culture and legendary personalities. Players are asked to guess the year of key milestones in current affairs, music, politics and entertainment. Every player guesses on every question in a race to earn letters and be the first to spell fun words, such as Pink Panther or Mellow Yellow, to win the game.

Name: Wellington
Description:
The publisher's description reads: "WELLINGTON is a puzzle-game of concentration and strategy inspired by the 18th century Pentomino concept. The Pentomino design--up to five connecting blocks in different shapes--is the basis for the game pieces in WELLINGTON, named after the capital of New Zealand in honor of Arthur Wellington, the 'Iron Duke.'"

The playing surface consists of a 10x10 grid, called the "town grid." A burgundy-colored T-shaped piece that covers four squares represents Parliament. Each player has a Duke, represented by a one-square obelisk. With Parliament and the Dukes placed on the board, players alternate turns in placing wooden blocks representing buildings in the city on the board. The objects are to capture the opposing Duke, capture territory, and capture buildings. Parliament, when captured, can be relocated to any available area on the board. Capturing the opposing Duke wins the game immediately. If neither Duke is captured, when no more buildings may be legally played the player capturing the most territory wins.

The publisher also included rules for a solitaire version.

According to the designer, fewer than 100 copies were produced.

Name: Cripple Mr. Onion
Description:
Cripple Mr Onion was originally a fictional card game played by characters in Terry Pratchett's novels Wyrd Sisters and Witches Abroad. This was used by Dr Andrew Millard and Prof. Terry Tao as the basis for an actual card game. The complete rules and design of this game were posted on USENET around 1993. It contains elements of blackjack and poker.

The rules as posted on USENET were approved by Pratchett himself.

The most notable aspect of the game is that it requires an eight-suited card deck: a deck using the normal suits (clubs, hearts, spades, and diamonds) must be shuffled together with a deck using the Spanish (and Tarot) suits (staves, swords, cups, and coins) yielding a complete deck with eight suits.

Each player receives a hand of ten cards: five cards are dealt face-down to each player, and the player may then discard up to four of them, receiving new cards to replace them. Then a further five cards are dealt face-up to each player except the dealer, who receives his face-down. The first player begins by assembling his or her cards into one of the winning groupings described below, and displaying them. The next player must then create a more valuable grouping or fold. If the player is successful in creating a more valuable grouping, the original first player may try again to create an even more valuable grouping for themselves, or fold. This process passes left around the table until only one player remains, who then wins the hand.

Name: Soldateska
Description: Soldateska is a trick-taking cardgame themed around Prussian military life.  Players attempt to win tricks by playing various dueling cards such as pistols and sabers.  The most successful duelist will attain the highest rank; while the inept will become a traitor.  Complicating things are a bomb, snuff, and Kokette, who officers cannot help but spend their upon.

Name: The Lord of The Rings
Description: In their First Action, players move forward one space along the Adventure Track. For their Second Action, players take an appropriately coloured Challenge Tile. Their Third Action involves resolving the challenge by rolling one, two or three dice to match of exceed the number on the Challege Tile. A player's Corruption Marker is moved along the Corruption Track the same number of spaces as the number of dice they have chosen. Players may used Reward Tiles they have acquired to add to their dice roll. If a player fails the challenge, play passes to the left. If a player is successful, then that player may take a Reward Tile or move on the attempt a further challenge. The game is over if a Hobbit Piece progresses to Mount Doom and destroys the One Ring, or if all players have become corrupted.

Name: Royal Armies of the Hyborean Age
Description: A variant of FGU's Broadsword rules designed to "make possible the recreation, on a table top, of the type of battle described in Robert E. Howard's Conan stories." There are rules for magic and a section giving descriptions and army lists of the forces of the various nations of the Hyborian age.

Name: Scream Inn
Description: "We're Only Here For The Fear!” A fast Game Full of Fun for 2, 3 or 4 Players. The object of the game is to get your players out of ‘Scream Inn’.  Beware there are ghosts under the beds and floor boards to ‘Boo!’ you at every turn. Place your ghosts in the board and spin the wheel to move them around. Try to get your marker out of the inn, without disturbing any ghosts.

Name: Speedy Eddy
Description:
From the Blue Orange Games website:

Somewhere in a secret vegetable garden, a few intrepid snails are preparing for the most exciting race of the year. Taking turns, roll the dice to help your snail progress. Watch out for mole holes, dodge flying carrots, and beware of the strong winds as your snails may lose its shell! Without a shell on its back, your snail goes slower so use the two dice with a touch of ingenuity to get a shell back on your snail and your snail back in the race. And win the famous Speedy Eddy Trophy!

Name: Bomben auf England
Description:
Bomben auf England, published by Spear Spiele, is a board game that was presumably available to German gamers at the star of World War II. The game involves a version of Tiddly Winks in which the tail of a "bomber" flicks chips on to a map of England, where English cities are the targets.

Pictured in the book Games We Play.

Name: Dong Wu Qi
Description:
å‹•ç‰©æ£‹ (doÌ€ng wuÌ€ qiÌ) literally translates into English as "Animal Game", though the name Animal Chess is more usually applied to Dou Shou Qi (which is better translated as Battling Beasts Game), from which this game is derived. The other progenitor game for Dong Wu Qi is Lu Zhan Jun Qi and it would be accurate to describe Dong Wu Qi as a hybrid between Dou Shou Qi and Lu Zhan Jun Qi.

In brief, the 8 kinds of animals in Dou Shou Qi are doubled for each player and pieces are placed face down on the board as in Lu Zhan Jun Qi rather than face up as in Dou Shou Qi. The board has similarities with Lu Zhan Jun Qi, with safe areas for animals to move into, and a base at each end of the board which the opponent is trying to get an animal into. The hierarchy of pieces is the same as in Dou Shou Qi, with the Elephant as the strongest piece, but susceptible to the Mouse.

Play is as in Lu Zhan Jun Qi - pieces are known only to their owner and combat (when a piece moves onto another) is resolved by a third person acting as a referee.

Unlike the traditional games of Dou Shou Qi and Lu Zhan Jun Qi, which many companies manufacture, Dong Wu Qi appears only to be made by one or two companies - currently, Da Fu Weng (Uncle Wang) produces this game.

Name: Narrow
Description:
UNAUTHORIZED PRODUCTION

    
    
         The information that BGG has on this item indicates that Narrow is a non-authorized version of Octiles.  According to game designer Dale Walton, Yi Qi Intellectual Toys does not have license to produce this game, thus it is set apart from the official entry of Octiles.

    


From Dale Walton:

"Octiles is a US registered trademark for my game. I own the trademark and have licensed this to Kadon Enterprises and Pin International. Listing Yi Qi Intellectual Toys as a publisher is damaging to the trademark, as it implies their game is from me, and would inevitably lead to damage to the value of the mark, and to my returns on invention of the game. For now they may be listed as the source only of Narrow - possibly in the same field that contains that game name, e.g. "Narrow from Yi Qi Intellectual Toys". Since I have not read their actual rules, I cannot say whether that game is an illegal copy/translation of mine, or a distinct game that belongs on a separate page. The board however is clearly designed to mislead in order to benefit from my design and my mark, and thus, if left on the site on whatever page, the pictures should be annotated as 'Unauthorised copy product, as identified by the author of Octiles'"

Name: Fühlo
Description:
A tactile memory game for 2-4 players age 3 and up.
Players search for the second of a pair by feeling the objects in a box.

Contents:
Large, colorful wooden box (50 x 50 x 20 cm) with 4 curtained holes to put your hand through
50 objects (25 pairs) in cloth bags

Name: Crazy Bluff
Description:
From the Blue Orange Games website:

Bluffing has never been this Fun ! Bluffer, Bluster and Bluffie get ready for some extreme bluffing as they race to be the first to get rid of all cards in their hands. Taking turns, players can match the last card played, draw or... bluff as all cards are played face down ! But watch out ! Don´t get caught bluffing because Bluff Busters are always on the watch

Name: Topitop
Description:
From the Blue Orange Games website:

Building Sand Castles has Never Been So Exciting! You will be given two buckets and a few sand piles. Taking turns, you will move sand piles or your buckets to build sand castles. But watch out! Protect your castle because your opponent may use it to build his own. The first player to complete two sand castles wins. A strategy-packed game that will challenge all ages.

Name: El juego de Makinavaja
Description:
The boardgame of Makinavaja, character created by Ivá in the pages of the satirical Spanish magazine " El Jueves ".

In this game every player is a delinquent who tries to commit a series of assaults, robberies and pulls in the streets of Barcelona. Taking care that the police doesn't detain him and takes it to the jail

Name: I have ...
Description:
"The game of quick reading and fast talking!"

A game for children aged 5 and up, to strengthen reading vocabulary and build letter recognition.

The first player reads the "I have" statement from the front of their card: "I have a snake" - then flips over the card and reads, "Who has a ...?" (eg a turtle).

Players race to be first to play an "I have a turtle" card onto the "Who has a turtle?" card. The first player to do this then flips their card and reads out the new "Who has a ..." question.

The game comes with 2 sets of 24 animal cards. It can be played by 2 with one set or by 3 or 4 with both the supplied sets.

Name: Maailman Ympäri Kilpapurjehdus
Description:
The name - Maailman Ympäri Kilpapurjehdus - translates from Finnish to Around the World Competition Sailing, and was developed in co-operation with the crew of the 1989 Union Bank of Finland-boat which participated in the Whitbread Round the World Race-sailing competition.

The map is divided into areas where different weather conditions occur. The players control boats, and must decide how much sail to apply to their boat, and then check to see how many steps they can move their boats towards the goal, depending on the weather.

Name: Planetenspiel
Description:
"Planetenspiel" or "Planets Game"

In a galaxy far far away, 7 suns are orbited by 2 planets each. These planets are home to the Plonx and the Quirx, who both feel they are the better tribe. The more common galactic option to prove superiority, open warfare, has been abandoned. Instead both tribes go head to head in an annual contest, using their ability to manipulate the speed with which their tribe's planets turn around the suns. The tribe that is most skillful at manipulating the planets in such a way that it manages to establish contact between tribe-members on neighboring planets most often, wins the tournament and gains the brag rights for that year.
 This is a highly abstract space game for 2 players that is a slight step away for a designer that is better known as a safe pair of hands for decent children's and family games. Manfred Ludwig shows here he can be equally at home with challenging the more abstract gamer as within its simplicity lies an engaging little dice less strategy game that isn't spectacular, but works surprisingly well.

The board shows a large sun on each corner of a hexagonal, and a seventh sun right in the middle of it. Another 3 lines are drawn that divide the hexagonal in 6 equal pizza slices. Then 6 planets are placed at equal distance in circular orbits around each sun, in such a way that the planets closest to a foreign sun are directly facing a planet of that sun. These are the possible meeting points.

Each player get 5 contact chips and places one tribe planet around each sun on the prescribed starting places. Then, in turn, each player moves one own planet. When a player ends a move by making "contact" with another planet of the own tribe, that player  claims one contact-chip of the opponent. The first player to own all chips wins the tournament.

Movement follows a strict pattern. Each player can only move one (own) planet each turn. The first player moves a planet exactly one space clockwise, the other player gets to move two spaces. Then moves of three, four and five spaces follow, and when a player has moved five spaces, the whole sequence gets repeated, starting with one. Planets can overtake each other, but moves that would result in planets landing on each other are blocked and force a player to move one of the other planets instead. In the rare cases that a player cannot move any own planets, the opponent gets to move instead.

Publishing history: this abstract game appeared in the German game magazine Pöppel-Revue (1987/2 April-MAY) as that edition's "Das Spiel im Heft". A pull-out board and rules were provided, players still needed to supply their own pieces (2x7 pawns and 10 contact-chips).

Name: Grab a Loop
Description:
“The Game that Really Grabs You” -- “You Loved Twister, Now Wait Till You Play Grab a Loop!”

Contents: 6 belts, each holding one each of red, yellow, green, blue, white and black detachable loops; 6 'goal pads.'

To start, players stand in a circle with one foot on their goal pad. You move off your goal pad once the loop-stealing begins. Game involves trying to grab loops of a particular color from your opponents while trying to keep others from stealing yours.

Name: Clean Sweep
Description:
The board is fenced except at the corners, where each corner has a square collection tray (with sides) of a distinct color. There are 4 brooms (look more like paint brushes) - one of each color. There is a garbage can in the center of the board filled with trash.

To begin, 'pop' the garbage can to send the trash flying and landing all over the board. Simultaneously, each player then tries to sweep the 'good' garbage into their own tray and the 'bad' garbage into opponents' trays. Score points for the good trash - a single piece of one kind of trash scores 5 points, two of a kind scores 15 points and three of a kind scores 25 points. Each piece of bad trash scores a negative point.

Highest point total wins.

It appears two versions of Clean Sweep were released.  The original(?) version has obstacles you attach on the board, additional colors of trash and brooms of different colors.  A second version has a different board, even though the picture on the box is the older version of the board, fewer colors of trash pieces and brooms are all the same color.

Name: Napoleon at Borodino
Description: A game on the battle of Borodino patterned after SPI's mini, Napoleon at Waterloo.  It has a number of movement allowances per turn for the French and their Allies (12 units) and the Russian (10 units), making it a matter of constantly allocating limited resources to achieve objectives.  As an added fillip, units in ZoCs count against the movement allowance.

Name: Cabbage Patch Kids Hide-And-Seek Game
Description:
from the box:

It's fun to play the Cabbage Patch Match! Just draw the top card from the deck and place it face-up in front of you. Then, slide the lever on the game unit and watch the kids rise out of the cabbage patch. Quickly--you don't have much time--find the kid who matches the kid shown on the card, and you're on your way to a win! Keep matching kids to cards until the kids go back into hiding and it's someone else's turn. The game is over when no more kids remain in the cabbage patch. Sounds easy, but you'll have to be fast to win this game! A good memory helps, too--try to remember, if you can, who's hiding where!

Name: Symbol-8
Description:
Symbol-8 is the Math game which uses some difficult functions as multiples, logs, square roots etc.

The basics of the game involve using the cards in your hand to change the number(not a number card, just a known number between the players) to another number which is integer between 0-100.

The aim of game:
The one who plays all cards from his hand first wins the game.

The number of players:
2-4, more if you play using more sets of cards.

There are 36 cards divided into 2 kinds of cards:(Reset cards, Functions cards)
1. Reset card:  have 4 different kinds of cards
   a) 8 CARD: Reset the number to 8.
   b) PRIME CARD: Reset the number to any prime number, eg.2,3,5,...89,97.
   c) 3 CARD: Reset the number to the multiple of 3. eg. 3,6,9,...,99.
   d) 0,64,100 CARD: Reset the number to 0, 64 or 100.

2. Functions card: contains 5 kinds of cards.
   a)MULTIPLE CARDS(x2, x3, x5, x10) : Each of difficult cards multiple the number to x2, x3, x5, x10. Eg. the number on table is 14. You can play x5 to change the number to 70. But you cannot play x10 because it is out of the range 0-100.
   b)DIVISOR CARDS(/2, /3, /5, /10) : Each of difficult cards divided the number to /2, /3, /5, /10.
   c)ADDITION or SUBTRACTION CARDS(+1, -3): Add or subtract the number same as the number on the card.
   d) SQUARE CARDS(X^2, X^(1/2), X^3, X^(1/3)): Square the number follow the card. eg. you use the card "X^2" to change the number from 8 to 64. Then the player next to you can use the card "X^(1/3)" to make the number 64 to 4.
   e)LOG CARD (log, log^-1): To log or log^-1 the number.

Beside two kinds of cards in function, there are 2 different color backgrounds on the side of the function.
BLACK BACKGROUND: The function cards except "addition or subtraction card".
BLUE BACKGROUND: The reset cards and "addition or subtraction card"(function cards)

Name: Dastardly & Muttley in their Flying Machines
Description: Based on the Hanna Barbera cartoon series. Each player has a pawn that represents one of the pilots, Dastardly, Muttley, Klunk or Zilly. The player attempts to fly around the board capturing pigeons, scoring the most points wins the game.

Name: The Original Food Lover's Trivia
Description:
Are you a food lover who likes trivia games or a trivia game lover who likes food? Whichever you are you'll love The Original Food Lover's Trivia game! This is the first game of its kind dedicated solely to food trivia. The game features 1,800 questions in the categories of Beverages, Geography and Culture, Ingredients, Recipes, Food People and Food Arts & Science. Game play is not confined to a game board, players gather their game pieces and get comfortable wherever they want to play! Teams of chefs are challenged by opposing teams of guests with trivia questions all about food. Players start with full plates and the winners are the first ones to Clean his Plate.

1. The starting chefs roll a 6-colored die.
2. The next team in line (the guests), draw a card and ask the question matching the color that the chefs have rolled on the die. The timekeeper starts the sand timer once the question has been read and understood.
3. If the chefs answer the question correctly, and before the timer runs out, then the chefs remove the matching color food chip from their "plate". That "food" (chip) is now considered "eaten" and the chefs roll again. "Eaten" chips should be returned to the game box or set-aside. Used cards are returned to the card boxes. Chefs must continue to answer questions matching the color they roll, even if they have already "eaten" the chip for that color category.
4. If the chefs give a wrong answer, then their turn is over, and play progresses in a clockwise direction to the next chefs in line.
5. The first chefs to "Clean Your Plate by "eating" all of their chips are the winners of DINNERTIME!

Over 40 recipes and party ideas are included so that the game can be played with edible game pieces in the game options; Play With Your Food, Potlucky, The Diet Plate Special and The Blue Plate Special.

There are also variant rules (including "Seconds Dice", which let you challenge other players), and suggestions for using real food instead of tokens (including recipes).

Name: Crazy Cocktails
Description:
[From the game packaging:]

Are you brave enough to play this game?

A crazy mix of Truth or Dare, Fact or Fiction and Sex Trivia, this daring game is definitely for the broadminded. The aim of the game is to collect 10 colored chips as you answer the questions, do the dares and drink the cocktails.

The outcome is a bawdy game that reveals all about the players. Ideal for girls nights in, mixed get togethers and after dinner parties.

All players should be over the legal drinking age and wild cocktail party freaks!

Name: Kitty Keeno
Description: A simple gambling game which consists of rolling dice and making or collecting payments in the form of chips.  Each player has a row of numbered tiles corresponding to the possible outcomes of the roll of 2d6, except 7.  On their turn if a player rolls a number equal to an un-flipped tile, they flip it; if the tile is already flipped their turn ends.  Rolling a 7 or 11 ('kitty') forces the player to pay a chip to the pot while rolling a 12 ('keeno') allows the player to collect the accumulated chips. The first player to flip all of their tiles wins the game and collects points based on the chips they have collected and the un-flipped tiles of their opponents.

Name: The Wright Brothers at Kitty Hawk
Description:
As of 2006, this game is produced in Seattle, Washington and sold in the souvenir shop at the nearby Museum of Flight. Players are assigned the roles of Wilbur and Orville Wright, each moving along their own separate track of 38 spaces. Movement is handled by flipping a coin, moving one or two spaces forward depending on the result.

Each track is peppered with trivia questions about the Wright brothers, which move the player an additional space forward if answered correctly. The first player to reach the end of their track is the winner.

The game is printed on the back of a large sheet of card stock, which is folded into a simple, 6-page book about the Wright Brothers, providing the basis for the game's trivia questions. Also included are two folded cards, one for each of the players, which contain the answers' to the opposite player's trivia questions.

Name: Oliphant Football Game
Description:
Art deco design vintage sports graphics on this 1930s football game. Box design features Oliphant front and center plus inset photographs of the following college football coaches:

Miller -Navy

Crisler -Princeton

Phelan - U of Washington

Neyland- Tennesee

Davidson -Army

Anderson –-Notre Dame

Wade - Duke

Kizer- Purdue.

Many other coaches endorsements listed including Knute Rockne and Pop Warner.

Game includes double sided wood playing board decorated as playing field with various field demarcations, OLIPHANT FOOTBALL GAME cards- full deck of 52 cards in decorated box, and a 20 pg instruction book.  Game play is mostly determined by card draw.

Name: Electric Derby
Description:
Electric Derby consists of five horses which are propelled by small ball bearings which hit the horses causing them to race down the track.  The winning horse hits a "flag" which springs up and clearly indicates the winner.

Each race has a different winner, hence the ability to bet on the outcome by using small tokens.  The motor drives the ball bearings in an irregular way which means that no one horse in the favorite.

Name: Sports Illustrated Trivia Game: Multi-Sport Edition
Description: Players attempt to answer sports trivia in 10 different categories: Baseball, Basketball, Football, Golf, Hockey, Motor Sports, Tennis, Olympics, Boxing, and Wild Card. Each trivia card is divided into five levels of difficulty, and the first player to correctly answer 15 questions wins the game.

Name: Business Game Amersfoort
Description:
A game for 2 to 4 players where the object is to place your tiles - you start with 25 - as close to the center of the city as possible.  Your tiles are 5 sets of 4 and if you can create a square of 4 matched tiles you can turn them over and they score at the end of the game.  The aim is to get all 5 sets of tiles on the board and scored.  You can also turn over individual tiles, in the hope that they form part of a matched set later on.

Movement/placement is via die rolls, one defines the x-axis placement and one the y-axis placement of the next tile.  If you get a double, you may get an extra (powerful) turn.

The game is designed to play on real maps of towns with the centre of the map defining the most valuable part of the town and is part of a series of (possibly) 36 games featuring 36 different Dutch cities.

Name: Star Fleet Battles: Commander's SSD Book #1
Description:
An expansion for the Star Fleet Battles: Commander's Rulebook.

Contains 48 SSD (Ship System Display) sheets for Star Fleet Battles.  15-Kzinti, 7-Orion, 4-Andromedan (7 ships) and 22-Federation SSD's.

Name: Star Fleet Battles: Commander's SSD Book #2
Description:
An expansion for the Star Fleet Battles: Commander's Rulebook.

Contains 48 SSD (Ship System Display) sheets for Star Fleet Battles.  19-Klingon, 15-Hydran, 9-Lyran and 5-Wyn SSD's.

Name: Star Fleet Battles: Commander's SSD Book #3
Description:
An expansion for the Star Fleet Battles Commander's Edition.

Contains 46 SSD (Ship System Display) sheets for Star Fleet Battles and a Supplement to the Master Ship Chart. 29-Romulan, 10-Gorn and 7-Tholian SSD's.

Name: Star Fleet Battles: Commander's Rulebook
Description:
The Commander's Edition of Star Fleet Battles was produced as a box set with counters, map, basic Ship System Display (SSD) sheets and a 96 page rulebook.

This is the separate "Rulebook Only" version with a blue 3-ring binder, available for previous owners of Star Fleet Battles who had the counters, map and the basic SSD sheets.  The rulebook was designed to be disassembled and put in a 3 ring binder.  New rules could then be added to the binder and rule updates and expansions replaced existing pages.

Name: Campaign Trail '96
Description:
Can you win the 1996 Election?

Gaffs, Media, Scandals, Spin Doctors, Jingles, Negative Ads, Road Trips, Millionaires, divisive Issues.  A politically incorrect, short-lived game.

Name: Heavy Panzers at Kursk, July 1943
Description:
HEAVY PANZERS covers the brutal and epic battle of Kursk tactically near Snovo on July 5th, 1943, with hourly turns, 400 yard hexes, platoon level units, armor strengths by tank type, aircraft, and engineers, in two scenarios using a chit-draw system so the game plays different each time.  The Firefight website describes the battle: "The Germans sent in their most powerful armor and even to their own surprise, broke through the first defensive line by 0930. The surrounded Russian regiment fought well and bled for it. The Tigers, Elephants and Brummbars became the King of the battlefield until met by the Russian Beast-eaters. Once the Germans had encircled the Russians in the first defensive line, there was a slight problem: their supporting infantry lagged far to the rear and what infantry had arrived was far too few to destroy the pocket. Immediately ahead was the 2nd Russian defensive line, manned by a Guards infantry division with armor. The first defensive line had crumbled under the classic German pincer movement, but German reserves were not ready to be committed. Nevertheless, piercing the 2nd Defensive belt and reaching the critical hills further south was not the same animal. It was nothing less than a head-on, in your face, battle. After regrouping, the German animals gathered in a armor wedge and began their breakthrough to the other side."
You must mount and cut out the counters and provide your own d6 and d10 to play this game.
